results.title: Small island, big fight
results.creator_credit: Aven S Noah, Rosemary Hesp, Trevor Graham, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Australia and Junjidys Productions
results.brief_description: …Where I come from is Murray Island. We call it Mer. The home of the famous Mabo land rights case. We won that battle, but now we’ve got a new fight on our hands…this time with outside fishing fleets over who can profit from our waters. (Aven S. Noah) Situated on the eastern side of the Torres Strait between Papua New Guinea and Australia, Murray Island or Mer, is home to around 450 indigenous people with each family belonging to one of eight clans. Following the historic Mabo case which won recognition for traditional ownership of their land, the Mer people are now fighting for the same recognition of their sea - land and sea are all part of Aboriginal territory and have a historical cultural link to their spiritual beliefs and customs. Their sea is being invaded by commercial fishing fleets and local islanders are struggling to compete - already some have left the Island and three-quarters of the population are on welfare. What has not been resolved by the Mabo case must now be resolved by the Torres Strait Treaty which was designed to protect indigenous rights to fishing and environmental concerns. The documentary presents all sides to the argument including interviews with the commercial fishermen, Mer Island fishermen and community leaders, and legal representatives for the Mer people as well as archival footage of Eddie “Koiki” Mabo discussing sea rights in 1989. Narrated by Aven S. Noah.

results.title: Small body of still water
results.creator_credit: Dietmar Fill, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A pond is a small body of still water. Within this environment the life support elements of sun, water and oxygen enable the process of photosynthesis to take place, upon which much of the life in and around the pond is dependent.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dietmar Fill, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: Slim pickings
results.brief_description: Using plasticene animation and miniature sets, motion control camera work and in camera effects, “Slim pickings” is a short animation mixing Hitchcock suspense with classic tragedy. On a hungry planet, a close friendship is tested. Cinematography by David Stevens.

results.title: Sleeping Beauty
results.brief_description: This production of the classic ballet, “Sleeping Beauty” is performed by the Australian Ballet. Performed live at The Victorian Arts Centre, October 9, 1984, this ballet in a prologue and three acts has the beautiful Christine Walsh dancing the role of Aurora with touches of tenderness and grace, and David Ashmole creating an outstanding Prince Florimund. Music is performed by The Elizabethan Melbourne Orchestra, conducted by Ritchie Hanna.

results.title: Sky sailing: waiting for the wind
results.creator_credit: Alex Ciecierski, Marie Schurrer and Huemark Films
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the preparation and inspection of the hang glider prior to use, and shows learners receiving preliminary training before their first jump. The hang glider is shown in action, with a commentary describing techniques of sky sailing. Narrated by Stacey Foster.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alex Ciecierski, Marie Schurrer and Huemark Films

results.title: Sky pirates
results.creator_credit: C M Pennington-Richards, Frank Godwin and Ansus Films
results.brief_description: When their model plane crashes at the Aero Club, Mike and Harry are befriended by ex-pilot, Charlie Bradford, and his niece, Maggie, who teach them to fly radio controlled planes. Charlie invites them to the test flight of his new long distance aircraft which is later stolen. When they learn that a diamond has been stolen from the French State Museum, they realise the plane is to be used to smuggle the diamond out of the country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: C M Pennington-Richards, Frank Godwin and Ansus Films

results.title: Sky
results.creator_credit: John Feeney, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: From the height of the Rockies on the rim of the western plains, the film catches and condenses the astounding spectacle of a day in the life of the sky. Photographed with many kinds of lenses and at different camera speeds, the result is a cinematographic experience of rare beauty - every changing mood of the sky is vividly registered. Film without words.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Feeney, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Slave hunter = Rancheador
results.creator_credit: Sergio Giral and Instituto Cubano del Arte e Industrias Cinematográficos (ICAIC)
results.brief_description: Against the historic backdrop of the colonial slave era in the Caribbean and other parts of Latin America, the figure of the Rancheador (slave hunter) appeared as one of the most abominable exponents of the system. The Rancheador, the mercenary of his era, was in charge of hunting down runaway slaves, the cimarrones, and returning them to their owners, or if the hunt ended in death, bringing back the slave’s ear. Francisco Estevez, one of the bloodiest and most ambitious slave hunters in Cuban history, was hired by the rich landowners to police the interests of absentee sugar growers. This film is based on the diary of Estevez himself, who not only hunted down the runaway slaves in their palenques (communities concealed in the hills, made up of runaway slaves), but also used his henchmen to repress all outbursts of rebellion or desire for freedom of those either white or black, free or slave. ‘Rancheador’ is the second film of Giral’s Slave Trilogy that also includes ‘The Other Francisco’ (1974) and ‘Maluala’ (1979). Adapted from ‘Diary of a Rancheador’ by Villaverde. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Slaughterhouse five
results.creator_credit: George Roy Hill, Paul Monash and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Kurt Vonnegut, an American P.O.W. is slipping into mental illness. Now a suburban optometrist, he has space/time fantasies, shifting between his experiences as a POW, including the bombing of Dresden, his life on another planet and his actual life. Michael Sacks plays Billy Pilgrim in a film shot in Czechoslovakia and Minnesota, which captures the complexity of Vonnegut’s work, and the despair of mental illness
